title: Sun Valley billionaire conference: media, tech and business moguls get together for annual talks | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The
text:
EVERY summer, America’s richest movers and shakers pack their Louis Vuitton bags, jump into their private jets and fly to attend what is known as the most luxurious summer camp in the world for billionaires.
Hosted by boutique investment bank Allen & Company, the 33rd annual gathering of about 300 executives, entrepreneurs and business owners — mainly from the tech industry — takes place in
Sun Valley, Idaho, lasts five days and is strictly off-limits to media.
The high life ... Exquisite scenery makes it easier to make huge deals, it seems. Picture: Sun Valley Resort, Instagram Source: Instagram
And while it may not be the usual celebrity gala, the guest list is certainly as impressive and the connections made there usually result in life-changing mergers and acquisitions.
Ready for new deals ... Sheryl Sandberg, chief operating officer of Facebook, attends the Allen & Company Sun Valley Conference on July 8, 2015 in Sun Valley, Idaho. Picture: Scott Olson/Getty Images/AFP Source: AFP
Cool shades ... Alexander Karp, chief executive officer and co-founder of Palantir Technologies Inc. Source: AFP
Think tank ... Evan Spiegel from Snapchat is there too. No sighting of his rumoured flame, Miranda Kerr. Source: AFP
This year, the lucky billionaires gracing the doors of the exclusive Sun Valley resort include: Telsa founder Elon Musk, media moguls Rupert Murdoch and Barry Diller, Jeff Bezos, Jack Dorsey, Sheryl Sandberg and Apple CEO Tim Cook.
Mingling time ... Apple CEO Tim Cook is one of the high-profile guests at the annual Allen & Company Sun Valley Conference for the world’s wealthiest and most powerful business people from media, finance, and technology. Picture: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP Source: AFP
Other bigwigs include New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, Universal Studios chairman Ron Meyer, Michael Bloomberg, Sony Entertainment chief Michael Lynton, Yahoo’s Marissa Mayer, The Weinstein Co.’s Harvey Weinstein, DreamWorks Animation’s Jeffrey Katzenberg, Paramount’s Brad Grey, CAA’s Bryan Lourd and Google’s Larry Page, Sergey Brin and Eric Schmidt.
... and Jack Dorsey, chairman and co-founder of Twitter Inc arrive at the Allen & Co. Media and Technology Conference in Sun Valley, Idaho. Picture: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg via Getty Images Source: Getty Images
Stacey Bendet, CEO & Creative Director of Alice + Olivia... Source: AFP
For instance, a 1995 gathering resulted in Disney’s acquisition of major American TV network ABC, while in 2012, social media giant Facebook bought Instagram for $1 billion .
Paradise ... This is what a billion dollar summer camp looks like. Picture: Sun Valley Resort, Instagram Source: Instagram
Other massive deals include:
-The merger between AOL and telecommunications giant Verizon, which bought AOL for $US4.4 million in 2014.
-In 2013, Amazon.com founder Jeff Bezos shocked the world when he bucked the trend and actually bought a newspaper, the Washington Post, for $US250 million. Only three months prior to that, he was spotted having long meetings with Post Chairman Donald Graham at Sun Valley, according to the Wall Street Journal .
Even billionaires wear name tags ... David Wehne, CFO of Facebook, Anthony Noto, chief financial officer of Twitter, and Dan Rose, VP of Business Development and Monetization at Facebook at the Sun Valley conference. Source: AFP
Traffic jam
But it’s not just major tech and media companies that are affected be the day: according to The Business Insider and CNBC , the event is considered one of the biggest for private jets, with officials at Friedman Memorial Airport expecting more than 200 jets to land on Tuesday alone.
Extra planes are projected to come and go throughout the week as the billionaires, tech tycoons and media giants hash out plans at the five-day mega conference.
The additional aircraft could also lead to a traffic jam and parking problems on the tarmac.
“It all depends on the size of the aircraft,” Rick Baird, airport manager for the Friedman Memorial Airport, told CNBC .
“If there are a lot more large corporate jets, then we could run out of room.”
